Title: Analysing ERP implementation critical success factors for SME: A study of sap one implementation in Jakarta
Source title: Pertanika Journal of Social Sciences and Humanities
Affiliations: Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Kemanggisan/Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Jiwasiddi, A., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Kemanggisan/Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Mondong, B., Management Department, BINUS Business School, Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Syahdan Campus, Jl. K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Kemanggisan/Palmerah, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Stimulating the development of local Small Medium Enterprises (SME) has been an important agenda for Indonesia to strengthen its local and regional economy. The SMEs here have their own unique characteristics. The government had set up Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system to improve SME’s business process and to share knowledge. However, implementing a successful ERP comes with its own challenges. This research investigated the factors that led to a successful ERP implementation. Using case studies, in-depth interview and observation at Trinity Era Aplikasindo, one of SAP representatives in Indonesia, as well as literature review, this study found factors such as Top Management support, good change management, and training have a significant impact on a successful ERP implementation in SME. This article discusses a comprehensive approach to understanding how ERP contributes to the success of SMEs. © Universiti Putra Malaysia Press.
Author Keywords: Business improvement; Critical success factor; Enterprise resource planning; Sharing of knowledge; SMEs

Authors: Jiwasiddi A., Suci R.P.N., Herman R.T., Weiss P.
Title: News website perceived quality; A comparative study for news websites in Indonesia
Source title: Proceedings of 2016 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2016
Affiliations: School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Tilburg University, Tilburg, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Jiwasiddi, A., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Suci, R.P.N., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Herman, R.T., School of Business and Management, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Weiss, P., Tilburg University, Tilburg, Netherlands
Abstract: The era of the conventional newspaper seems to be so far behind, technology has changed many aspects of life, one of them is how the information sharing works. On past years people has started to shift from newspaper to their computer, smartphones, and tablets. This will create changes not only on the nature of how news being consume but also how the news is being produced. This research is conducted as a preliminary research, using qualitative approach and literature studies. The objective of this research to understand more about the behaviour of news website readers and understanding what perceived to be a better quality news website for readers. Results of this research indicate that even though people tends to favor the website interface and news content. The Websites that they access more frequently is indeed a different website, which offers more values such as pleasure and variety. The complete research and result can be read in the full paper. © 2016 IEEE.
Author Keywords: e-business; Indonesia; news website; perceived website quality; website
Index Keywords: Information management; Newsprint; Comparative studies; eBusiness; Indonesia; Information sharing; Literature studies; News websites; Qualitative approach; Website quality; Websites

Title: How does product type, trust, risk and perceived value affect online purchase intention?
Source title: Heritage, Culture and Society: Research agenda and best practices in the hospitality and tourism industry - Proceedings of the 3rd International Hospitality and Tourism Conference, IHTC 2016 and 2nd International Seminar on Tourism, ISOT 2016
Affiliations: Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Universitas Indonesia, Depok, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Jiwasiddi, A., Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Balqiah, T.E., Universitas Indonesia, Depok, Indonesia
Abstract: Internet shopping is continued to rise significantly each year. In the beginning, online shopping is dominated by products in search category such as books and CD’s, what interesting is in the last few years one of the most increasing number of products purchased online are clothing products, an experience product that is considered high risk for online purchase, along with that reason is the fact that research about value and perceived trust in internet shopping is still limited, this research is going to investigate how product type, trust, risk, and perceived value affect the consumer online purchase intention. Using online questionaires, findings shows that few criteria can be applied for both product category; book and clothing. Perceived value have significant impact in increasing purchase intention for both product categories. Perceived Risk turns out to be not negatively impact purchase intention for both products/website. The role of trust doesn’t give a significant impact in this model And there are a strong evidence that pleasure have a significant effect to perceived value on both of the product category. Results and the complete finding of this research can be read in the full paper. © 2016 Taylor & Francis Group, London.
Author Keywords: Online perceived value; Online shopping; Product category
Index Keywords: Purchasing; Sales; Internet shopping; Online shopping; Perceived risk; Perceived trusts; Perceived value; Product categories; Product types; Purchase intention; Electronic commerce
